content: hi I'm Tim Holliday and I'm going to show you how to cook scrambled eggs in the microwave things you will need a microwave a fork two eggs a microwave safe Bowl one teaspoon of milk salt and pepper the first thing to do is to crack the eggs into a microwave-safe bowl and discard the shells in the trash next add a teaspoon of milk into the bowl on top of the eggs briskly stir the mixture with a fork place the bowl into the microwave for 30 seconds and cook on high heat carefully take out the bowl as it will be hot stir the eggs again and place them back into the microwave for 20 seconds add in the desired amount of salt and pepper and continue cooking until light and fluffy remove the bowl and let cool for one minute before eating and that's how you cook scrambled eggs in the microwave

content: today we're making Mumsnet microwave scrambled eggs for those days that you're in a bit of a rush or when you just can't be bothered they are great for mornings great for after-school and you can pack and full of veg or just have them completely natural whatever suits you and your family best to get started you're going to need two eggs per person salt and pepper butter a bowl knife and fork and that's it it really is that simple to start you're going to grease your bowl with some butter just to make sure that the eggs don't stick to the bowl once you put them in the microwave and this also gives the eggs just a nice little bit of texture and that little bit of extra flavor right your bowl is greased and ready let's crack those eggs and then you just beat the eggs until the yolks are all mixed in if you want them slightly fluffier or if you're feeling a bit fancy a dollop of creme fraiche or a little bit of a drizzle of milk would be great but if you're dairy-free from you like we are probably not the best option then just a bit of seasoning and if you're adding veg the siz the time as much salt and pepper as you're comfortable with your family having or as much as they're willing to eat and then you're ready for the microwave [Music] yeah it's need 45 seconds in the microwave take them out give them a stir and pop them back in if they need it but make sure they're not 100 percent cooked but reasonably firm because they will keep cooking from the inside [Music] so obviously the microwave cooks the eggs but you want them scrambled so take them out give them a stir and a scramble the kids'll never know so give them a stir break them up make sure they've got that lovely scrambled texture and that was the Mumsnet microwave scrambled eggs made in under five minutes perfect for the when you're rushed off your feet or just a little bit low on energy and effort and they taste good - hmm while I'm eating these why don't you click on the Big M subscribe and then you'll get notifications whenever we upload a new video whether it's recipes hacks all things parenting from Mumsnet and you'll be the first to know now don't mind me

title: How to Make Scrambled Eggs in a Microwave
original_title: Microwave Scrambled Eggs
content: hi I'm Allen from the sports nutrition department don't have time in the morning for breakfast well if you have two minutes you sure do having breakfast when you wake up will give you quality fuel for your morning workouts and jumpstart your energy levels for the rest of the day one easy way to do this is to make eggs in the cup start out with a microwavable mug and lube it up with either canola oil spray or little olive oil rubbed in by hand crack one or two eggs into the mug and beat until scrambled add some salt and pepper and throw it in the microwave for 45 seconds take the mug out give it a good stir and throw it back in the microwave for another 30 seconds that's it your eggs are done if you want add some toppings here like shredded cheese and salsa so there you have it eggs in two minutes with easy cleanup but don't stop there make it a complete breakfast add a piece of whole wheat toast and you've got a winning combo of carbs and protein for more sports nutrition videos links and posts check out our YouTube Twitter and Facebook pages I'm Alan and thanks for watching

you need a microwave-safe bowl you could use a coffee cup not a mug it's a little too deep but a regular standard coffee cup or another small bowl as long as it's microwave safe melt about 1/2 a tbsp which is a teaspoon and a half of butter in the bottom because you don't want it to stick roll it around so that it gets out to the sides pick your egg crack drop it in now comes the tricky part don't skip this part what I have here is just a standard stick pin cleaned put a little peroxide on it too I'm going to pierce the white and a couple of spots just break through the membrane and once through the egg yolk that's because there's going to be some pressure some build up in the microwave and we don't want the egg to explode now I'm going to put a little salt on skipping the pepper to subscribe check out my breakfast series or the series on bacon

title: How to Make Scrambled Eggs in a Microwave
original_title: How to Make Scrambled Eggs
content: scrambled eggs are made from yolks and whites that are mixed together they can be cooked and stainless steel however nonstick makes for easier cleanup the eggs can be lightly blended before cooking for a more uniform color but because scrambled eggs are cooked over low heat you can also do this right in the pan butter cream or milk can be added directly to the eggs for extra creaminess cook the eggs over medium low heat and stir continuously with a rubber spatula texture is determined by how often the eggs are stirred for the creamiest scrambled eggs with tiny curds constantly and quickly stir and scrape the bottom and sides of the pan be patient and keep scrambling until the eggs start to coagulate you can take the pan off the flame to control the heat and slow down the cooking process once the eggs are set but still a bit undercooked like this turn off the heat the residual heat from the pan will finish cooking the eggs seasoning the eggs is better done near the end of cooking because the salt breaks down the protein in the egg which can make the eggs watery the eggs can also be finished with cheese herbs or anything you like these eggs may look like they are too runny but just try making them once you will be amazed at their creamy and delicate texture many people prefer scrambled eggs with larger curds to do this simply stir less often and a bit slower scrambled eggs can also be cooked over higher heat just keep in mind that the higher the heat and the longer the eggs are cooked the tougher and sponger they will become but really there are no strict rules it all comes down to how you prefer your eggs

original_title: How-to Microwave Eggs - Food Science
content: hi I'm dr. Kiki Sanford and today on food science we're talking microwaves [Music] have you ever wanted hard boiled goodness but not had the time to dedicate many of us have probably resorted to the microwave at one point or another I know that I have tried popping an egg into the microwave on at least one occasion but then you learn your lesson anyone having to clean a gout of a microwave probably won't repeat the mistake but what just happened microwave ovens work by creating electromagnetic waves in the form of microwaves that energize the electrons in molecules microwaves have wavelengths of one millimeter to one meter in length microwave ovens have a device inside of them called a magnetron which produces strong rapid pulses of microwaves DC pulses are created within the microwave ovens power supply which electrically heat a cathode causing it to release electrons with the help of a strong magnet beams of electrons are sent to special chambers that resonate at 2.45 gigahertz the frequency at which microwave ovens operate an antenna then transmits the current from the magnetron to the cooking chamber as microwaves microwaves primarily affect molecules that are polar in nature by making them rotate to remain aligned with the alternating electrical field of the microwaves as they rotate some of the molecules bump into each other the resulting friction converts kinetic energy into heat microwaves can pass through nonpolar materials that do not conduct electricity and that do not contain water this lets them penetrate more deeply into foods more rapidly than conventional cooking methods in the case of our poor egg here the microwaves excited the water molecules inside the egg to boiling this led to steam buildup inside the egg that increased the pressure enough to cause it to explode but is it possible to cook an egg in the microwave in its shell without having it explode I found a gadget that says it'll let me do just that the microwave egg boiler this microwave egg boiler consists of a lid an aluminum tray and a well for water but aluminum in the microwave well it turns out that as long as there are no sharp edges notice this tray is nice and round there's no place for the electrical current created in metal objects by microwaves to collect and create a spark if you inspect your microwave you'll notice that the cooking chamber is metal walled title: How to Make Scrambled Eggs in a Microwave
original_title: How to Make Perfect Scrambled Eggs
content: how to make perfect scrambled eggs everyone and their mother claims to make the best scrambled eggs we're no different which is not your mom you will need a small frying pan preferably a heavy one with a nonstick surface a plastic spatula or wooden spoon a small bowl a fork or whisk 1 to 2 tablespoons of butter 2 or 3 eggs and some salt and pepper optional a little water a little milk and 1 teaspoon of fresh herbs like thyme oregano or chives step 1 crack the eggs into the bowl and beat with a fork or whisk until the whites and yolks are completely blended these eggs that are straight from the refrigerator rather than room-temperature eggs for best results step 2 add salt and pepper to taste if you've woken up hungry for a little adventure you can also add 1 teaspoon of thyme oregano chives or any other fresh herbs for fluffier eggs beat in one to one-and-a-half tablespoons of water per egg for creamier eggs add 1 tablespoon of milk per egg step 3 warm the frying pan over low heat you can tell when the pan is warm by holding your hand about 6 inches above it you should feel a dull heat coming off its cooking surface step 4 slowly melt the butter in the warm pan when it begins to foam you're ready for the eggs if the butter turns brown you're overheated the pan and should start over step 5 pour your egg mixture into the pan and let stand for about 10 seconds or as long as it takes for the eggs to begin setting for fluffy occurred let the egg mixture sit 10 to 20 seconds in the pan before stirring step 6 stir the egg curds gently with the plastic spatula or wooden spoon to one side of the pan and allow the uncooked portions to run to the other side continue to stir gently as the curds continue to form step 7 cook and stir for two to five minutes or until the eggs are firm but still moist did you know the most common area eaten in the u.s. comes from the single comb White Leghorn chicken

content: [Music] mmm-hmm check out this delicious microwave poached egg on this video I'm gonna show you how to make a delicious poached egg in about 90 seconds plus I'm gonna show you a way to slide the yolk on to the toast without breaking it hi folks welcome to kitchen tips online the a YouTube channel where you can learn new and innovative ways to do things in the kitchen and if this is your first time here well I invite you to have a look around check out some of our other videos and consider subscribing please remember if you do subscribe to ring the bell so that Google will send you notifications when we post a new video the easiest way to cook poached eggs in your microwave is to bring one cup of water to a boil now the times going to vary depending on how powerful your microwave is these Pyrex measuring cups are perfect because the handle does not get hot notice the water is actually boiling we're gonna drop the egg in there and then put it back in the microwave for about 30 seconds you'll have to adjust the amount of time based on how powerful your microwave is and whether or not you like super runny eggs now the last thing you want to do is break the yolk as you retrieve the egg from the boiling water let me show you a very simple and easy way to do that instead of using a spoon trying to scoop out the egg we'll just pour the egg onto a plate and lean it over so that the water will run into a bowl in this case here but normally this is something you would do over the sink we'll let the water run off the plate and leave the egg behind then we can just slide the egg right on to the toast if you like poached eggs now you know how to cook the eggs almost faster than you can cook the toast well there you go folks perfect microwave poached eggs and if you think we did a good job on this video a thumbs up would certainly be appreciated thank you very much thanks for watching [Music]

title: How to Make Scrambled Eggs in a Microwave
original_title: How to Make Scrambled Eggs | Light, Fluffy and Moist in Just a Few Minutes!
content: howdy on the quirky cowboy and today on kitchen ax light fluffy and moist scrambled eggs [Music] all right eggs eggs are so darn versatile I love eggs I'm very particular on how my eggs are cooked whether they're scrambled poached over easy making an omelet or even hard-boiled turned into deviled eggs so if you want to check out any of those other videos in my channel about how to cook eggs feel free to subscribe and click those like buttons for me but anyways back to today's eggs scrambled eggs the reason why you clicked on this video I'm going to show you some tips and tricks on how to make gritty scrambled eggs alright let's crack 3 eggs into a bowl and whisk them together here's a tip that will save you lots of trouble crack an egg on a flat surface if you crack omelet sharp surface like the edge of the pole you're definitely more likely to get eggshells in your eggs but if you do just use the edge of the shell to scoop it out it'll save you lots of time now let's add some oil or butter to your pan aggghhhhh really good non-stick pan helps a lot when making eggs and especially one that heats evenly so heavier-weight the pan the better let's preheat the oil for about 10 to 15 seconds we don't want to heat it too much so when when you put our eggs in that they sizzle we do not want them to sizzle we're not frying eggs we are scrambling eggs and to get nice and fluffy scrambled eggs we need to take our time so eggs should take almost 5 minutes to cook if you take your time you're definitely going to have a better chance of getting light and fluffy and moist eggs so we want to work in a circular figure 8 pattern scrambling our eggs vigorously occasionally shaking the pan helps a lot too when you also want to move your pan off the heat and back on to the eat remember we don't want our eggs to cook too quickly you'll start to see that your eggs are starting to coagulate and that is a good sign this is about a minute or so into the cooking process at this point it's a good idea to remove it from the heat again do not cook your eggs too quickly when you fill your pan is cooling down some you can move it back onto the heat about this time you want to push your eggs to the middle of the pan creating a nice collection in the center this will help keep your eggs fluffy by the time they're done now it's a good time to start folding your eggs the firmer they get folding adds air bubbles and keeps them again light and fluffy and moist so again off the heat when your pan starts to get too hot and your eggs are cooking too quickly if you notice I'm just now putting salt and pepper into my eggs there are about ten or fifteen seconds away from being done if you do it now your eggs will be fluffy because the salt prevents your eggs from coagulating so do not put them in at the start of the cooking process you will have flat and non fluffy eggs now you can serve your eggs on a nice crusty piece of bread or just by themselves or with bacon any time of the day eggs are great like that and delicious and there you have it perfectly fluffy and moist scrambled eggs just follow these simple techniques and YouTube will have great scrambled eggs in no time if you like this video click that like button if you want to see more useful tips and tricks in the kitchen by me the quirky cowboy click the subscribe button don't forget to
